playn.core
Interface Image

All Known Subinterfaces:
AsyncImage<I>, CanvasImage, Image.Region, SurfaceImage
All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractImageGL, ImageGL, ImageRegionGL, SurfaceImageGL
public interface Image

The base image interface. See CanvasImage and SurfaceImage for specialized variants.

Nested Class Summary
static interface Image.BitmapTransformer
          Used with transform(playn.core.Image.BitmapTransformer).
static interface Image.Region
          A subregion of an image.

Method Detail

width

float width()
This image's width in pixels.

height

float height()
This image's height in pixels.

scale

Scale scale()
Returns the pixel-scale of this image. This will be Scale.ONE unless HiDPI images are being used.

isReady

boolean isReady()
Whether or not this image is ready to be used.

addCallback

void addCallback(Callback<? super Image> callback)
Adds a callback to be notified when this image has loaded. If the image is already loaded, the callback will be notified immediately; otherwise on the main playn thread at a later time. The callback is discarded once the image is loaded.

repeatX

boolean repeatX()
Returns whether this image repeats in the x direction. See #setRepeatX.

repeatY

boolean repeatY()
Returns whether this image repeats in the y direction. See #setRepeatX.

setRepeat

void setRepeat(boolean repeatX,
               boolean repeatY)
Configures whether this image repeats in the x or y direction (rather than scaling) when used in a layer whose width or height is larger or smaller than the image. Both axes default to false.

subImage

Image.Region subImage(float x,
                      float y,
                      float width,
                      float height)
Returns an image that draws the specified sub-region of this image.

Parameters:
x - the x offset (in pixels) of the subimage.
y - the y offset (in pixels) of the subimage.
width - the width (in pixels) of the subimage.
height - the height (in pixels) of the subimage.

toPattern

Pattern toPattern()
Creates a Pattern that can be used to use this image as a fill in a canvas. This pattern will repeat based on the image's repeat configuration.

getRgb

void getRgb(int startX,
            int startY,
            int width,
            int height,
            int[] rgbArray,
            int offset,
            int scanSize)
Extracts pixel data from a rectangular area of this image. This method may perform poorly, in particular on HTML and Flash platforms - avoid using this if possible. The returned pixel format is (alpha << 24 | red << 16 | green << 8 | blue), where alpha, red, green and blue are the corresponding channel values, ranging from 0 to 255 inclusive.

Parameters:
startX - x-coordinate of the upper left corner of the area.
startY - y-coordinate of the upper left corner of the area.
width - width of the area.
height - height of the area.
rgbArray - will be filled with the pixel data from the area
offset - fill start offset in rgbArray.
scanSize - number of pixels in a row in rgbArray.

transform

Image transform(Image.BitmapTransformer xform)
Generates a new image from this image's bitmap, using a bitmap transformer created for the platform in use. See JavaBitmapTransformer and IOSBitmapTransformer. This does not work on sub-images nor SurfaceImages.

setMipmapped

void setMipmapped(boolean mipmapped)
Configures the use of mipmaps when rendering this image at scales less than 1. This only applies to GL-based backends (it is a NOOP on other backends).

ensureTexture

int ensureTexture()
Creates a texture for this image (if one does not already exist) and returns its OpenGL texture id. Returns 0 if the underlying image data is not yet ready or if this platform does not use OpenGL. The texture will remain in GPU memory until clearTexture() is called or this image is garbage collected.

Note: this texture handle should not be held for longer than the scope of the enclosing function call. It is not safe to hang onto an image's texture handle as the image may delete its texture and recreate it under any number of circumstances.

clearTexture

void clearTexture()
Clears the GPU texture associated with this image, on platforms implemented via OpenGL. Does nothing on non-OpenGL platforms. In general it is not necessary to call this method. Images added to ImageLayer instances automatically clear their texture when the image layer is removed from the scene graph. Textures are also cleared when the image is garbage collected. However, if you manually call ensureTexture(), or if you draw images to a Surface, you may wish to clear textures manually to avoid running out of GPU memory before garbage collection has a chance to run and clear the textures for you.
